text.p: Brazilian telephone holding Telebras SA rose strongly Thursday, boosted by inflows from Brazilian mutual funds.

Telebras was up 5-3/8 to 159-3/4, above a 12-month closing high. Volume was a moderate one million shares in late morning, putting Telebras's American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) among the most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange.
Telebras has risen steadily in recent weeks. It stood at 121-1/2 on May 14 and has rocketed up from 76-1/2 at the start of the year.
The stock's recent rise has been caused by "local buyers coming out of the mutual funds in Brazil as interest rates have come down," a trader said.
"Those guys really have been driving it, along with some option buying," the trader said.
Robert Pelosky, a principal at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said in a June 25 analysis that the amount of Brazilian mutual fund assets invested in equities was on the rise.

At the beginning of the year, 96 percent of Brazilian mutual funds assets were in fixed-income funds, drawn by the high real yields paid by Brazilian government bonds. However, by the end of May the equity share had risen to 10 percent.
"Over the last 12 months, equity assets have increased by around 400 percent, compared to 51 percent for total assets under management," Pelosky wrote.
Among other Latin American ADRs, Mexican shares moved higher, boosted in part by rumors that Standard & Poors might upgrade Mexico's long-term currency rating, traders said.
An S&P spokesman denied the rumors.
Telefonos de Mexico was up 9/16 to 48-1/8, and Vitro SA rose 5/16 to 10-3/8.
French drug and chemical group Rhone-Poulenc SA rose 6-7/8 to a 12-month high of 43 after the company said it would buy the 32 percent of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc it did not already own.
Rhone-Poulenc said it would pay $4.3 billion for the remaining shares. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's shares rose 11 to 90-7/16 in very heavy volume.
Among other active ADRs, Singaporean software company Creative Technology Ltd rose one to 17-3/8.
Advancers led decliners 273 to 199 among 814 ADRs. The ADR group rose 0.31 percent and volume in late morning was 32.5 million shares.
ADRs allow U.S. trade of foreign shares.
